event.title: addressed a crowd of more than 220 Wednesday evening

data.event: However, as the author addressed a crowd of more than 220 Wednesday evening in the Grand Reading Room of Eastern Kentucky University’s library, Flood called upon living history portrayer Bob Coffey to illustrate a scene depicted in his latest book, “1864: Lincoln at the Gates of History.”

However, as the author addressed a crowd of more than 220 Wednesday evening in the Grand Reading Room of Eastern Kentucky University’s library, Flood called upon living history portrayer Bob Coffey to illustrate a scene depicted in his latest book, “1864: Lincoln at the Gates of History.”

Captured Confederates later said their snipers recognized Lincoln’s unmistakable profile, but all of their bullets missed the president who would be felled by an assassin’s bullet the following year after the soldiers’ guns had fallen silent.

Alluding to scandals of the past 35 years that have sent three Illinois governors to prison and led to another’s indictment and impeachment, “It’s not that hard for an Illinois politician to acquire a reputation for honesty,” Flood said to much laughter.
“What I have (at EKU) makes me competitive with people working in any university or large public library anywhere in the country,” he said Wednesday.

event.title: began with a handful of supporters from years

data.event: “We began with a handful of supporters from years past and now have nearly 200 members of our friends group thanks to Bracelen’s leadership.”

event.title: many days as soon as the doors open and often doesn’t leave until late into the evening,” she said

data.event: “He is in the library many days as soon as the doors open and often doesn’t leave until late into the evening,” she said.

Co-sponsored by the Friends of Madison County Public Library and Friends of the EKU Libraries, Wednesday’s event also featured an exhibit of Civil War documents, including a Lincoln letter from the university’s archives, a pass the president signed for a Kentucky civilian to go through Union lines at Louisville and a parole for a Union soldier and member of the Kentucky Home Guard who was captured at the Battle of Richmond.

Author Bracelen Flood answers a question Wednesday night about his latest book, "1864: Lincoln at the Gates of History," during a presentation in the Grand Reading Room of the EKU library as part of a Lincoln bicentennial celebration.
